DOC.brief_summary: The purpose of this study is to assess if a therapy with oral and intravenous moxifloxacin is as effective as a therapy with intravenous ceftriaxone + intravenous azithromycin followed by oral amoxicilline/clavulanate and oral clarithromycin in the treatment of community-acquired pneumonia.
DOC.brief_title: A Study to Assess the Efficacy and Safety of IV/PO Moxifloxacin in Subjects With Community-acquired Pneumonia
DOC.criteria: Hospitalized nonICU patients (age, >= 18 years) Clinical signs and symptoms of CAP, with PSI score IV or V Radiologically confirmed evidence of a new and/or progressive infiltrate(s) Requirement for initial parenteral therapy At least 2 of the following conditions: Productive or non productive cough with or without purulent or mucosus or mucopurulent sputum Dyspnea and/or tachypnea (respiratory rate of > 20 breaths/min) Rigors and/or chills Pleuritic chest pain Auscultatory findings of rales and/or crackles on pulmonary examination and/or evidence of pulmonary consolidation Fever (an oral temperature of >= 38 째C, a rectal temperature of >= 39 째C, or a tympanic temperature of >= 38.5 째C) or hypothermia (rectal or core temperature of < 35 째C), and a WBC count of >= 10,000 cells/mm3 or >= 15% immature neutrophils bands; regardless of peripheral WBC count) or leukopenia (total WBC count of < 4500 cells/mm3) Written informed consent PSI Class IIII and V with need for ICU admission Hospitalization for > 48 hours before developing pneumonia, or discharge from hospital < 30 days prior. Note: patients currently residing in residential longterm facilities can be enrolled in the study
